Topic.Title: Has Nvidia dumped their tegra yet?

Message.Msg: Performance does not matter if the thing runs real hot, and does not have an LTE chip to pair with. Dump the tegra nonsense, and focus on gaming. AMD is carving out a niche in gaming, and is pushing Nvidia out.

Topic.Title: Has Nvidia dumped their tegra yet?
Has Nvidia dumped their tegra yet?

Message.Msg: You are an annoying freak..no one listens to you

Topic.Title: Has Nvidia dumped their tegra yet?

Message.Msg: long term, stock price follows fundamentals. In this case, Tegras not only losing big money every Q, but the loses are increasing and Jen has zero idea how to turn that around. This stock should be in the single digits. And you want the stock price to do what now???

If you believe it is truly worth more, "load up". I am patiently long the stock and am using the low prices to add to my position on dips. The key is to relax and realize you are making an investment. If you believe the story, don't worry so much about day-to-day price movements. If you are here for a trade, then I suggest you find a different stock. ARMH, DDD, and others in the tech space are likely better bets in the NT.

Message.Title: Nvidia Is Now Claiming Tegra 4 Is Faster Than 80% of Ultrabook Processors Sold Today
Message.Msg: My goodness...what is with this advertising campaign against Intel? See MWC-PDF on their website. Perhaps Microsoft is working on extending Windows RT to 64 bit sooner than most think and Nvidia wants Tegra 4 to be the processor of choice. After all Microsoft Surface RT is a steady seller as it expands distribution around the world---20 countries today, 26 by the end of March.

Topic.Title: Nvidia Is Now Claiming Tegra 4 Is Faster Than 80% of Ultrabook Processors Sold Today

Message.Msg: Ahhhh...[T4] A15/ARMv7 (IS) is a 32bit architecture. Maybe I'm confused by the context but I am guessing WinRT 64bit would be moot without involving an OS subsystem and some thunking mechanism to down address etc...basically a hyper visor.

Topic.Title: Nvidia Is Now Claiming Tegra 4 Is Faster Than 80% of Ultrabook Processors Sold Today

Message.Msg: Win RT-64 Bit comes later this year. Might even have legacy app support. But seriously if ARM doubles performance every year and Intel increases performance 15% to 20% a year, what do you think the competitive landscape will look like next year. Just another thought if little ole Nvidia can build a processor that is comparable to Ivy bridge what do youthin Apple will do on Mac Airs next iteration. Fancy ultrabook at 1/2 the price...No Wintel tax at all. ARM and IOS. Just a thought.

Topic.Title: Nvidia Is Now Claiming Tegra 4 Is Faster Than 80% of Ultrabook Processors Sold Today

Message.Msg: After fooling around with a Surface at Staples, I found that it's a slick looking device that has a good feel to it. I'm sure if Apple came out with it instead it would be all the rage with long lines. MSFT's poor marketing, and pricing decisions sure have not helped things out. Perhaps this was a soft release with more aggressive X-box advertising, pricing, and availability, in the future?

Message.Title: NVDA is a no-growth story - -THATS WHY ITS UNDER 200 M.A. WHICH INDICATES A STRONG "SELL"
If a stock trades below its 200 m.a. and CAN"T rise above it, it means big funds are SELLING to keep it in bear market
BEAR MARKET for Nvidia -- it CANNOT CROSS ABOVE 200 m.a. with Dow at ALL-TIME HIGHS, Markets smashing records
CHIPMAKER Texas Instruments has signed a deal with HP for its Keystone II ARM chips...
Message.Msg: "Texas Instruments, which last year said it was trying to sell parts of its chip business including its largely unsuccessful mobile chip unit, has pulled off a major deal that could see its system on chip (SoC) parts end up in mass deployed servers. HP announced that Project Moonshot had signed up Texas Instruments to supply quad-core Keystone II 66AK2Hx SoCs1 based on the ARM Cortex A15 architecture."
I'm looking for great articles. Nice to be here.

I understand your frustration...truly I do. But, as Ibexx so aptly said, yesterday, it will take MORE volume to get us to break out. I'm quite surprised, though, that the volume has really dried up, here, and don't quite understand why at least ONE of the big shareholders (Fidelity, Paul Tudor Jones, et al) hasn't been willing to be the one to FORCE the breakout above the 200DMA. It's to THEIR benefit, and I can't figure out if it's just a game of "chicken" and that no one wants to be the first to make that push. All of that said, it will probably happen when we least expect it, and all of a sudden their will be a major surge in both volume AND price and that will set off alarm bells for a lot of technicians. As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. Best, Max

NVDA needs something new... IMO, their entire future will pivot around their own ARM64 CPUs... patience, patience... Tegra has fallen one year behind schedule... sad & unfortunate... but true... IMO, they've become top-heavy... especially the Tegra team, multiple merging companies along with NVIdia's internal teams... but I stick around for they're doing cool stuff... and I'm expecting ARM64 to be HUGE !!

Topic.Title: Nvidia Is Now Claiming Tegra 4 Is Faster Than 80% of Ultrabook Processors Sold Today

Message.Msg: J7, I totally get that. I personally think that the ARM offering will be competitive and in many cases advantageous in both the desktop and server market. ARM and CO are just starting to explore that space, so it's coming. I will tell you from experience that Intel and MS ABSOLUTELY DO have reason for concern here. However, to clarify my original point T4 and the A15 WON'T run a 64 bit code with out a layer of abstraction (software) in between. Simply said - 32 bit hardware is not capable (well in most conventional inceptions) of running 64 bit code. That beings said; I would be willing to bet that we, as you mentioned, we will see an ARM (A50 - most likely) in Macs but it won't happen, I think, until there is a 64bit ARM chip out there (which T4 is not) unless as you seemed to suggest that they downgrade the Air to iOS - but I highly doubt it, if for nothing else, because of SW compatibility. Essentially you'd create Apples version of RT by doing this.

Topic.Title: Nvidia Is Now Claiming Tegra 4 Is Faster Than 80% of Ultrabook Processors Sold Today

Message.Msg: "Win RT-64 Bit comes later this year. " where did you find ?? Must have ARM64 CPUs first...

Topic.Title: Nvidia Is Now Claiming Tegra 4 Is Faster Than 80% of Ultrabook Processors Sold Today

Message.Msg: Apple, Nvidia and a host of others including Microsoft have architectural licenses for ARM 64 and are designing chips....perhaps Microsoft is just writing code. Not this years Mac Air iteration...just a slight bump from an Intel Chip, but next year's iteration Intel will be out of the Mac Air. Think how cheap Apple can make a fancy ultrabook without Intel and Microsoft. Why do you think Microsoft brought out Win RT...to test the waters I believe and apparently they like what they see because they are expanding distribution world wide.....26 countries at the end of March. JMHO

Message.Title: Verizon
Message.Msg: What do you make of the story Verizon wants to dump CDMA. Go entirely lte to cut out royalty costs. Story said it will be done 3q 2013 to early 2014. Interesting time line? I'll defer to those with more knowledge. What.s with the early analyst meeting Thursday. Must be something important to say!
getanid has zero association with this one
Is this what you think too?

What they are going to say ; T4 a huge hit but cant give on OEm names but a lot more than T3 see more tablet wins and smartphones wins to quadruple over 2012 PC Gaming to pick up as new titles in PC space release later in 2013 Titan is selling liek hot cakes at $1k each Sheild getting great reviews - no competition in sight And so sure up our earnings outlook and buy out loosk good because our phone is ringing off the hook with Ballmer and Schmidt calling, begging us to do a deal

1) What Verizon can do the Chinese can do just as fast. 2) Very Bad News for Qualcomm 3) Eventually the days of $800 phones for $199 will be over with everyone paying the same data rates. Cheaper phones may get cheaper data rates. Consumer wins and Verizon wins. I mean afterall they really are just phones IMHO. 4) A whole lot of very good enough Smartphones powered by smaller die cheaper to make chips like Tegra 4i will be sold. 5) It's good that Nvidia thru their purchase of Icera and their joint purchase of 500 IP wireless patents with IV Investments has a presence in LTE patents. Qualcomm might just want to get nasty because CDMA makes them about $6B a year or something like that and they certainly do not have a lock on the LTE patents like they do on CDMA The analyst meeting is just the 3rd in a series of investor conferences in the last week.
Have you got a link to that story? I'd be interested in reading it! Thanks. Max

Message.Title: Intel has 63% of graphics marketshare in Q4, up from 60% in Q3.
Message.Msg: By the end of 2013, Intel will have 70% of the graphics marketshare, and Haswell will not yet have hit its stride. Game Over!! All this tegra nonsense, and Nvidia has its eye of the ball. AMD is killing it in gaming, and Intel is killing it in PC's.

Vis-a-vis what I said, earlier, you might want to go look at the intraday chart, with volume, on the Nasdaq site. At 3PM, we had only done 5.178mm shares, and the stock was stuck at 12.74-75. By 3:04PM, we had 6.178mm shares and the stock had some huge blocks trade on upticks, getting to 12.77-78. After another attempt to take it back down, the volume got to 7.876mm at 3:50PM, before things heated up and the stock hit its high of the day just before the close, and volume the final hour came to almost 4mm shares or nearly 80% of the entire day until 3PM. You can clearly see the huge spike in volume right after 3PM if you look at that chart. Now, of course, I would rather have seen the volume more than double, to get us 10-12mm shares, but even still, I saw exactly what I was looking for....BIG blocks being bought on UPTICKS, and no real give back at the close, even though the rest of the market did sag at the bell. The "simple" 200DMA is at 12.68, but the "exponential" 200DMA is at 12.83, and that might be what folks are looking at. And, no, I can't explain how they're calculated. Regardless, today's close was the HIGHEST CLOSE since January 4th. Tomorrow should be interesting. As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. Best, Max

Topic.Title: Intel has 63% of graphics marketshare in Q4, up from 60% in Q3.

Message.Msg: I totally disagree with you on the ARM64 CPUs role in their growth. I think the comments about Tegra's schedule is overplayed and they have been using their R&D for many of the thing s we are seeing right now. I think the Tegra line is positioned better then Qualcomm's lineup for a longer time period as they have identified the real growth drivers with quality smartphones, tablets and the like at a price point below $300, around the $200 range. We're in better shape now and we'll continue to hear releases and news items build on the solid base we have now. The ARM64 will have a role long term but the real growth drivers are being setup right now imo.

"I totally disagree with you on the ARM64 CPUs role in their growth." then you're in for a BIG surprise... in a very good way !!! " I think the comments about Tegra's schedule is overplayed" If Tegra was here a year ago, as was scheduled, it would've had an impact far greater than today...
Is this what all the Analyst are saying?

First of all, it has to do with VoLTE availability in handset devices otherwise CDMA will have to stay for voice support. Secondly, it’s no secret that VZ has been planning to phase out its 3G (CDMA) network and that any newer models sold in 2014 won’t have CDMA support. It’s called phasing out. The fact is VZ cannot abandon CDMA network for at least until 2015 because they still have millions of customer using their CDMA devices. VZ cannot expect customers to suddenly dump their CDMA devices and buy LTE because most customers are still under contract.

Topic.Title: Intel has 63% of graphics marketshare in Q4, up from 60% in Q3.
